intro: Aalius sumatrana, commonly known as the Sumatran aalius, is a rare flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Sumatra. It belongs to the family Arecaceae, which includes palms, and is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and large, pinnately compound leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers that are typically yellow or greenish in color, arranged in panicles at the top of the stem. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies in Southeast Asian rainforests. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
taxonomy_art_desc: Aalius sumatrana belongs to the kingdom Plantae, phylum Magnoliophyta, class Liliopsida, subclass Commelinidae, order Poales, family Poaceae, genus Aalius, and species sumatrana. It is a grass species native to the island of Sumatra. This plant is characterized by its slender stems and narrow leaves typical of the grass family. It plays a role in the local ecosystem and may have traditional uses by indigenous communities. Further research is needed to fully understand its ecological and economic significance.
